title: HomeGoods Is Bringing Back This 175-Year-Old Decor Trend for the Holidays
description: “The plates are stunners!” one shopper wrote. READ MORE...
author: Ashia Aubourg
excerpt: “The plates are stunners!” one shopper wrote.

All prices were accurate at the time of publishing.Credit: Raymond C. Eichelberger/ShutterstockThe High Victorian Gothic era boasts bold, contrasting hues and dramatic architecture. It peaked in Europe in the mid-1800s and was characterized by pointed arches, stone columns, and intricate window tracery. Like many vintage styles, the bold contrasts and aesthetics of this period continue to resurface in modern decor.On your next visit to HomeGoods, you may spot a set of Victorian Gothic-esque plates decked out in this ornate style if you’re lucky. Shoppers posting their hauls on TikTok are especially enamored with the delicate yet bold designs on these plates tucked away in the kitchenware aisle. The plates, which come in green and brown, according to TikToker Kayla Seah’s (@kaylaseah) video, feature an array of intricate designs, including floral touches, a bridge with arched structures, clustered stone columns, and a towered building with window tracery. If you weren’t familiar with High Victorian Gothic style before, these plate designs are a great introduction to it.The HomeGoods dishes aren’t available online, but you can take a look in your nearest location to see if they have any left.You may want to go soon because shoppers are loving these dishes. In Seah’s TikTok video detailing the dinnerware, one person commented on this post, saying, “The plates are stunners!” while another user called out, “Ahh, so good! I gotta go now.”If you can’t find this gem at HomeGoods, try T.J. Maxx’s website, where you can find plates with similar Victorian vibes. The brand’s Tonquin set comes with four dishes for $29.99. They’re navy blue and white and boast intricate patterns and designs from this vintage era.

From the moment I started remixing ramen noodles into gourmet meals and spending hours watching cooking shows as a puny six-year-old, I knew I found a deep passion for food. While I realized — after taking on a two-year high school internship in an award-winning kitchen — that a…read more

published now

We independently select these products—if you buy from one of our links, we may earn a commission. All prices were accurate at the time of publishing.

The High Victorian Gothic era boasts bold, contrasting hues and dramatic architecture. It peaked in Europe in the mid-1800s and was characterized by pointed arches, stone columns, and intricate window tracery. Like many vintage styles, the bold contrasts and aesthetics of this period continue to resurface in modern decor.

On your next visit to HomeGoods, you may spot a set of Victorian Gothic-esque plates decked out in this ornate style if you’re lucky. Shoppers posting their hauls on TikTok are especially enamored with the delicate yet bold designs on these plates tucked away in the kitchenware aisle. 

The plates, which come in green and brown, according to TikToker Kayla Seah’s (@kaylaseah) video, feature an array of intricate designs, including floral touches, a bridge with arched structures, clustered stone columns, and a towered building with window tracery. If you weren’t familiar with High Victorian Gothic style before, these plate designs are a great introduction to it.

The HomeGoods dishes aren’t available online, but you can take a look in your nearest location to see if they have any left.

You may want to go soon because shoppers are loving these dishes. In Seah’s TikTok video detailing the dinnerware, one person commented on this post, saying, “The plates are stunners!” while another user called out, “Ahh, so good! I gotta go now.”

If you can’t find this gem at HomeGoods, try T.J. Maxx’s website, where you can find plates with similar Victorian vibes. The brand’s Tonquin set comes with four dishes for $29.99. They’re navy blue and white and boast intricate patterns and designs from this vintage era.
